channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Israeli Airstrikes Target Gaza as Conflict Rages On
item.description: Diplomatic efforts have stalled, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel saying it “will take some time” to “restore order and quiet.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mahmud Hams/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli warplanes targeted Gaza City on Monday morning.

item.title: India's Black Market Preys on Desperate Covid-19 Victims
item.description: As the health care system fails, clandestine markets have emerged for drugs, oxygen, hospital beds and funeral services. Fake goods may be putting lives at risk.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unloading oxygen canisters, a precious commodity in India, at a New Delhi hospital this month.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Fighting Raises Questions about War Crimes
item.description: Civilian deaths on both sides raise urgent questions about which military actions are legal, what war crimes are being committed and who, if anyone, will be held to account.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian boy in front of the ruins of his house in Gaza City on Friday after it was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: A Scratched Hint of Ancient Ties Stirs National Furies in Europe
item.description: Czech archaeologists say marks found on a cattle bone are sixth-century Germanic runes, in a Slavic settlement. The find has provoked an academic and nationalist brawl.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: An archaeological excavation in the Czech Republic at Lany, near the border with Austria, a few yards from where a bone scratched with Germanic runes was found.

item.title: Tel Aviv, Israel’s Bustling Financial Hub, Shaken as Rockets Rain Down
item.description: The largely liberal, secular beachside city has a reputation for being a hedonistic bubble. But during the past week, Tel Aviv has been targeted by at least 160 rockets.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Gideon Markowicz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Beachgoers run toward shelters in Tel Aviv on Saturday after rockets were fired from Gaza.

item.title: Covid Is Killing Young Children in Brazil, Baffling Doctors
item.description: Experts believe Brazil’s overloaded hospital system and uneven access to health care are among the reasons babies and small children are succumbing to the virus at a high rate.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ariani Roque Marinheiro at her home last month in Maringá, Brazil. Her daughter, Letícia, a toddler, died in February from Covid-19.

item.title: Far-Right Leader Rebrands for France's Presidential Election
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader and main challenger to President Emmanuel Macron in next year’s election, wants to persuade voters that she and her party can govern France.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The far-right leader Marine Le Pen posing next to a statue of Marianne, symbol of the French republic.

item.title: Tens of Thousands Evacuated in India Ahead of Cyclone Tauktae
item.description: The cyclone is expected to make landfall on India’s northwest state of Gujarat on Sunday evening.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Indranil Mukherjee/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fishermen secure their boats in a village near Mumbai on Sunday, ahead of Cyclone Tauktae.

item.title: Grief Mounts as Efforts to Ease Israel-Hamas Fight Falter
item.description: The diplomatic wrangling came as at least 42 Palestinians were killed early Sunday in an airstrike in Gaza City, the deadliest episode in the recent bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: Iyad Abuheweila and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian man who survived an Israeli airstrike in Gaza on Sunday mourned the loss of his wife and three children.

item.title: Glimpses of a Deserted Soviet Mining Town, Preserved in the High Arctic
item.description: On the remote archipelago of Svalbard, a slowly decaying settlement offers visitors an intimate look at the not-so-distant past.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Lafferty
item.media:credit: Jamie Lafferty
item.media:description: The dusty entrance to Pyramiden’s chemical plant.

item.title: In Taliban-Controlled Areas, Girls Are Fleeing for One Thing: an Education
item.description: Two districts in Afghanistan’s northwest offer a glimpse into life under the Taliban, who have completely cut off education for teenage girls.
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Female high school students inside Marshal Dostum School, where over two dozen girls from Darzab and Qosh Tepa districts study.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Deaths surpass 200 in Israel-Gaza crisis.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bomb hits the Jala Tower during an Israeli airstrike in Gaza city May 15, 2021

item.title: Unvaccinated People Are Most at Risk by Unmasking, C.D.C. Director Says
item.description: In a round of Sunday morning news, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky sought to quell the public confusion over her agency’s new masking guidance.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel, Mitch Smith and Christina Morales
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Greg Nash
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky during a Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee hearing last week.

item.title: Bleachers collapsed inside a crowded synagogue, injuring more than 100.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman
item.media:credit: Gil Cohen-Magen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish men and children gathering at the scene where a grandstand seating at a synagogue collapsed in the West Bank settlement of Givat Zeev on Sunday.

item.title: Netanyahu says there is no clear end in sight, and airstrikes begin again.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:credit: Fatima Shbair/Getty Images
item.media:description: Palestinian civil defense men search for people in the rubble of a destroyed building after an Israeli air strike in Gaza City on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Carried Out Deadly Airstrike on Gaza
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building on fire in Gaza City following an Israeli airstrike overnight.

item.title: Israel’s Gaza Strikes May Cause Covid Surge, U.N. Warns
item.description: The officials see the possibility of the virus spreading among unvaccinated Gazans cramming into shelters during Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Mohammed Salem/Reuters
item.media:description: A staff member of the World Health Organization receives a Covid vaccine in March in Gaza City.

item.title: In pictures: A wave of violence grips the Middle East.
In pictures: Fire and thunder fill the night sky as Israel’s Iron Dome is tested.
item.description: The system that protects Israeli cities has had to intercept a barrage of rockets over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Anas Baba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Israel's Strike on Media Building in Gaza Provokes Outrage
item.description: Media groups demand explanations after Israeli forces destroyed the high-rise that housed the offices of The Associated Press and other news outlets.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee and Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike destroys a high-rise building in Gaza City that housed the offices of The Associated Press and Al Jazeera on Saturday.

item.title: In Washington, Hundreds Take Part in Pro-Palestinian Protests
item.description: News of the march to the U.S. Capitol spread largely through social media and word of mouth, including during Friday prayers at local mosques.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters gather near the Washington Monument on Saturday in downtown Washington.

item.title: Australia’s First Repatriation Flight from India Returns Half Empty
item.description: The Australian government says 70 people were barred from boarding the plane after they or someone close to them tested positive for Covid.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: STEWART GOULD/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Australians who were stranded in coronavirus-ravaged India have touched down in Darwin on the first post-ban repatriation flight.

item.title: Nurses’ Union Condemns C.D.C.'s New Mask Advice
item.description: National Nurses United, the largest U.S. union of registered, nurses called on the federal agency to revise its guidance, saying that “lives are in the balance.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bonnie Castillo, executive director of National Nurses United, last year in Oakland, Calif. Ms. Castillo is condemning the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s lifting of mask recommendations for vaccinated people.

item.title: Greece Opens Its Doors to International Tourists
item.description: Greek television showed islanders on Mykonos, one of the country’s most popular summer destinations, painting cobblestone streets with whitewash in anticipation.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Stefanos Rapanis/Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers arriving from Germany and Switzerland at Heraklion Airport on Saturday, on the Greek island of Crete, as the country’s tourism season officially opens.

item.title: Biden Calls on Israel and Palestinian Leaders to Protect Civilians
item.description: President Biden backed Israel’s right to defend itself while urging the nation to protect civilians after the Israeli military destroyed a building housing the offices of journalists.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: Journalists in the rubble of the Jala Tower in Gaza City, home to offices of The Associated Press and Al Jazeera, which was destroyed in an Israeli air strike on Saturday.

item.title: Yitzhak Arad, Who Led Holocaust Study Center in Israel, Dies at 94
item.description: A survivor of the Nazis, Mr. Arad was an esteemed scholar and the longtime chairman of the Yad Vashem complex of museums and archives in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Fragile Ceasefire Lets Afghans Risk Travel for Eid
item.description: A 3-day cease-fire is violated, but Afghans brave dangerous roads to celebrate a holiday with families.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Faizi and David Zucchino
item.media:credit: Hedayatullah Amid/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A mosque on the outskirts of Kabul was bombed during Friday prayers, killing at least 12 people, including the imam.

item.title: Several Everest Climbers Test Positive for Covid
item.description: Anyone who becomes infected “at high altitude, then develops symptoms and becomes ill, is very difficult to help,” a climbing company official said.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Prakash Mathema/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Expedition members wearing face masks at Mount Everest base camp on May 1. A prominent mountaineering company abandoned its summit expedition on Saturday after more climbers were found to be infected with the coronavirus.

item.title: Greek Neo-Nazi With Seat in European Parliament Is Sent to Prison
item.description: Ioannis Lagos was a leading member of the extreme-right and now-defunct Golden Dawn, which rose to political prominence in 2012 at the peak of the Greece’s financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Costas Baltas/Reuters
item.media:description: Ioannis Lagos, Greek member of the European Parliament and former member of the extreme right Golden Dawn party, is escorted by anti-terrorism police officers to the prosecutor's office in Athens on Saturday.

item.title: Why Vaccinating the World Against Covid-19 Will Be Hard
item.description: When President Biden joined a push to set aside patents for Covid shots, he entered a roiling debate over how to ensure poor countries get enough vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Apoorva Mandavilli, Rebecca Robbins and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health workers waiting to enter a vaccination center at Charlotte Maxeke Johannesburg Academic Hospital in Johannesburg, South Africa, last week.

item.title: South Africans Call for Justice After Police Shooting of Lindani Myeni
item.description: A Black man from South Africa was shot and killed in an encounter with the police in his adopted home, Hawaii. His countrymen want answers.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Michelle Broder Van Dyke
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lindani Myeni’s widow, right, and an aunt holding the couple’s daughter, greeted his returning coffin at the Johannesburg airport.

item.title: Violence in Israeli Town Carries Echoes of 1948 for Palestinians
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, left, signing a document in Tel Aviv proclaiming the new Jewish state of Israel on May 17, 1948, as Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok witnessed.

item.title: Conflict Spirals Across Israel and the Palestinian Territories
item.description: An American envoy landed in Israel for cease-fire talks with Palestinians and Israelis. But as of Saturday evening, there was no sign of a letup in fighting and a media center in Gaza was destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tower in Gaza City, which housed the offices of The Associated Press and Al Jazeera, was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike on Saturday.

item.title: What Is Happening in Israel and Gaza? Here's What to Know.
item.description: A little-noticed police action in Jerusalem last month was one of several incidents that led to the current crisis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem last month, about a week before the start of Ramadan.

item.title: Shootings in New York spiked during the pandemic, and may outlast the virus.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Times Square, where three people, including a toddler out toy shopping, were shot last Saturday.

item.title: Over 70 Percent of Older U.S. Adults Are Fully Vaccinated
item.description: The proportion of those with full protection is much higher among older Americans than among younger people.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: People over 65, who are much more likely than younger people to become seriously ill from Covid, have been a high priority since the U.S. vaccination campaign began.

item.title: An Israeli airstrike killed at least 10 members of a family in a Gaza refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Adam Rasgon, Iyad Abuheweila and Irit Pazner Garshowitz
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral for people killed in an Israeli airstrike on the Shati refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: An annual day of Palestinian grievance comes amid the upheaval.
item.description: Nakba Day on Saturday denotes the 1948 displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians amid Israel’s declaration of independence.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Abbas Momani/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstration marking Nakba Day in Ramallah, West Bank, on Saturday.

item.title: Tensions Among Democrats Grow Over Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
item.description: Divisions within the party have burst into public view, with the party’s ascendant left viewing the Mideast conflict as a searing racial justice issue that carries echoes of U.S. politics.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York and other progressive members of Congress delivered impassioned speeches about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on the House floor on Thursday.

item.title: Syria’s Surprising Solar Boom: Sunlight Powers the Night in Rebel Idlib
item.description: Cut off from the power grid and with fuel costs soaring, Syrians in a poor, embattled enclave have turned en masse to solar panels to charge their phones and light their homes and tents.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solar panels covering rooftops, some of which have been damaged in government attacks, in Binnish, Syria.

item.title: Israel Strikes Gaza Building With A.P. and Other News Outlets
item.description: President Biden spoke to the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians. Hamas militants aimed another round of rockets at Tel Aviv and protests spread to the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee, Lara Jakes and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike destroys a high-rise building in Gaza City that housed the offices of The Associated Press and Al Jazeera on Saturday.

item.title: Taiwan Reports a Daily Record of 180 Cases
item.description: The self-governing island, which has had striking success with the virus, ramped up restrictions in Taipei after reporting 180 locally transmitted infections.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Ritchie B Tongo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Disinfecting seats at a Covid-19 testing site in Taipei on Saturday.

item.title: A Press Corps Deceived, and the Gaza Invasion That Wasn’t
item.description: A spokesman led the international media to believe that Israeli forces had entered Gaza. They hadn’t. But the army wanted Hamas to think they had.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers at a staging area near the border with Gaza on Friday.

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian Strife Widens as Frantic Calls for Calm Go Unheeded
item.description: While Israel and Hamas signaled willingness to consider a cease-fire, worries grew about further fracturing in one of the Middle East’s most intractable struggles.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli ground forces at a staging area near the border with Gaza on Friday.

item.title: Why the C.D.C. Changed Its Mask Guidance
item.description: Two scientific findings altered the calculus: Vaccinated people rarely transmit the virus, and the shots are effective against variants.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masked and unmasked pedestrians walked around Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: Chad Kalepa Baybayan, Seafarer Who Sailed Using the Stars, Dies at 64
item.description: He was a torchbearer for the celestial navigation art known as wayfinding, which ancestral Polynesian sailors used to navigate the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul

item.title: When the Bus No Longer Rolls Into Town
item.description: The final shutdown of Greyhound bus service in Canada will add to a growing accessibility problem for rural communities.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Helgren/Reuters
item.media:description: Greyhound ended its bus service in Western Canada in 2018, and this week shut down in Ontario and Quebec as well.

item.title: Arab World Condemns Israeli Violence but Takes Little Action
item.description: By saying it is defending Jerusalem, Hamas has made it harder for Arab countries not to denounce Israel. But in a changed region, the response so far has been rhetorical only.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem reflected in a damaged door inside the Aqsa Mosque compound on Friday.

item.title: In Israel’s Rising Violence, Ripples From 1948
item.description: The town of Lydda posed an early test of how the Israeli state would treat Palestinians. It is a legacy playing out today in violence between Jews and Arabs in Lod, as it’s now known.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: What was known as Lydda in 1948, the year Israeli forces breached the town and exchanged fire with militiamen. Hundreds of Palestinians, including many civilians, were killed, and nine Israeli soldiers died.

item.title: Gaza Rocket Finds a Rare Gap in Israeli Armor, and a 5-Year-Old Boy Is Killed
item.description: When a rocket struck an Israeli border town, Ido Avigal, 5, was sheltering in a fortified safe room. But shrapnel still managed to puncture the thick window, killing him.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome antimissile defense weapons, designed to intercept incoming rockets and artillery shells, in Sderot.

item.title: Eight people from the New York Yankees organization tested positive, despite having been vaccinated. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Andy Marlin/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Gleyber Torres, center, at Yankee Stadium last week in the Bronx.

item.title: British Fraud Unit Is Investigating Gupta and Greensill
item.description: The inquiry will focus a spotlight on a steel magnate and a financier whose business collapse has provoked a scandal in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Ben Stansall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sanjeev Gupta, head of the Gupta Family Group Alliance, which is being investigated on suspicion of fraud and money laundering.

item.title: Prince Harry Shares ‘Pain and Suffering’ of Growing Up in Royal Family
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview for a podcast, Harry said his existence in the British monarchy had been “a mix between ‘The Truman Show’ and being in a zoo.”
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Jason Armond/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Harry at a concert in California this month. He now lives in the state with his family.
